title: Understanding Spontaneity of Vaporization
text: To determine if water will spontaneously vaporize at a certain temperature, we need to evaluate the change in Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG) for the process at that temperature.

title: Formula for Gibbs Free Energy Change
text:
The change in Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG) is calculated using the equation:

ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - T * ΔS

where:
- ΔH is the change in enthalpy (molar enthalpy of vaporization)
- T is the temperature in Kelvin
- ΔS is the change in entropy (molar entropy of vaporization)

title: Determine if ΔG is Negative
text: For a process to be spontaneous, ΔG should be less than zero. Calculate ΔG using the formula:\n\nΔG $$=$$ $$\frac{40.79kJ}{mol}$$ - 350K * $$\frac{0.1092kJ}{K} mol$$.

title: Calculate ΔG at $$350$$ K
text:
Let's calculate the Gibbs Free Energy change at $$350$$ K:
ΔH $$=$$ $$ rac{40.79kJ}{mol}$$
ΔS $$=$$ $$ rac{0.1092kJ}{K} mol$$.
T $$=$$ 350K

Therefore, ΔG $$=$$ $$40.79$$ - $$350$$ * $$0.1092$$

title: Conclusion from calculated ΔG
text: Now that you have calculated ΔG $$=$$ $$\frac{2.57kJ}{mol}$$, is $$\Delta G<0$$? Is the process spontaneous at 350K?
